channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-19148] Reevaluate default values of configurations
item.description: Remove cruft and mythologies. Make descriptions more digestible. Change defaults given experience.

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Will just mention a few of the configs that we run with where I wonder if the default should be reconsidered. Apologies if some of these have already been changed.

  • hbase.master.loadbalance.bytable=true - If running with tables with different workloads or profiles, it can be surprising to find a single table very unbalanced on the cluster. Seems like it might be less surprising to keep each table independently balanced. A tricky one I think.
  • hbase.regionserver.fileSplitTimeout=600000 - Painful when the largest region splits are the ones that fail, and gets stuck in a cycle where they fail worse.
  • hbase.regionserver.logroll.multiplier=0.5 - With the default of 0.95, whenever write load was significant, we saw many log files that had a little bit more than 1 HDFS block worth of data. Seemed a waste.

Don't feel strongly about any of them, but curious to see what other folks are thinking.
Excellent. Thank you davelatham.

The default value of hbase.client.retries.number is 35. This can be a small value?
1. For our unit test, if we don't set this, the ut may hang a very long time.
2. In out production use case, some user didn't set this to small value, so some operation will hang a long time and don't throw the exception. It is hard for us to debug what happened.
Yeah. It is sort of obnoxiously long. Too save. What you think zghaobac? Lets set it now so time to evalute it before release? Set it to 3? 10?
+1 for 10. The request will fail fast for some exception, like RegionMovedException or NotServingException. So 3 is too small.

Lets set it now so time to evalute it before release?

Agreed. This may affect some ut which use default config.
The default value 0.1f for replication.source.ratio is also very less, we should increase it, there is a jira also to handle that HBASE-16499
Attach a patch for retry number to see the hadoop QA results.

-1 overall

Thanks ashish singhi for adding link. Anything else you'd suggest we'd change sir?

One another config need revisit is hbase.client.serverside.retries.multiplier. The default value is 10. Then the default retries number is 35. So the default server side retry number is 350. It is too big!

It is too big!

Yes. By about 300. Good one. Thanks.

hbase.client.serverside.retries.multiplier - the way it's being used in code...funny!
One, there's a mixed default of 1 and 10 (3 places each).
Second, in the places where it's 10, 1 out of 3 use it to multiply, and rest 2 use it to divide and get back to original value of 35.
As the retries number effect too many unit test, I open a new issue HBASE-19359 to see the Hadoop QA result. stack appy

davelatham some questions sir

I think 'hbase.master.loadbalance.bytable=true' makes sense as default on big cluster where tables are big, less so on small cluster (i think). Looking at the stochastic balancer, it has this in the class comment:

  • <p>This balancer is best used with hbase.master.loadbalance.bytable set to false
  • so that the balancer gets the full picture of all loads on the cluster.</p>

Let me add this config to hbase-default so folks see at least it is there.

hbase.regionserver.fileSplitTimeout=30000 in branch-2. This better?

hbase.regionserver.logroll.multiplier=0.5 - With the default of 0.95, whenever write load was significant, we saw many log files that had a little bit more than 1 HDFS block worth of data. Seemed a waste.

So, we'd run over the block size because 0.95 doesn't give us enough wiggly room within which to close the WAL? We could come down from 0.95. 0.5 seems way down. We'd make lots of files – a pain in itself. Set it at 0.8? Should we up the default block size?
Small amount of change. Guanghao did important ones in a linked issue.

-1 overall

This message was automatically generated.

Thanks for taking a moment to consider, mighty stack.

hbase.regionserver.fileSplitTimeout=30000 in branch-2. This better?

That's the existing default in what we were running too, but we found 30 seconds was not enough for some large regions under load.

I think 'hbase.master.loadbalance.bytable=true' makes sense as default on big cluster where tables are big, less so on small cluster (i think).

I'm not convinced of that. I think if you have multiple tables with different workloads, it is often helpful to balance them out, even in a small cluster. It seems more likely for things to go significantly wrong when each table is not balanced and you wish they were than when each table is balanced but you don't really need it.

So, we'd run over the block size because 0.95 doesn't give us enough wiggly room within which to close the WAL? We could come down from 0.95. 0.5 seems way down. We'd make lots of files – a pain in itself. Set it at 0.8? Should we up the default block size?

That's right, 0.95 didn't give enough wiggle room, and we frequently went over 1 block, sometimes by a little, sometimes by a lot. We found it better to just bump up the block size, and make this low enough to be sure we never exceeded the block. Then in all the files were no larger or more frequent, but less extra fractional blocks. Maybe we should just increase the block size for the WAL files along with turning down the logroll multiplier.

In all, I don't think any of these are critical issues, and don't mind if none are changed, just thought it possible others may benefit.

That's the existing default in what we were running too, but we found 30 seconds was not enough for some large regions under load.

Oops. Thanks davelatham Let me up it to what works on your cluster. I see too that the config has changed in hbase2 now splits are run by master. Config is now called hbase.master.fileSplitTimeout. Updated patch so it respects hbase.regionserver.fileSplitTimeout if set.

Let me do your suggestion of doubling the block size and tuning way down the 0.95 threshold to 0.5 so we are more likely to avoid block transition yet we'll be making WALs of about same size. Good one.

I put a mail up on the dev list to see if any objection to balance-by-table. Will just implement unless objection.

Thanks for feeding us back your experience running in prod Dave.

.002 adds the Dave Latham suggestions that we wait longer on splits to complete by default and that we give log roll more runway. Also fixed it so regionserver-side split log timeout will be picked up if set and used for master-side timeout if present.

-1 overall

Hey, I am not sure this is the correct place, but just wanted to update you that under HBASE-19282 I am changing the default of MemStore's ImmutableSegment to automatically use CellChunkMap (CCM) as an index (CellSet) in case when MSLAB usage is configured (on-heap or off-heap). Alternatively, CellArrayMap index is going to be automatically used when no MSLAB is defined. This is based on recent benchmarking with CCM that we have done. No specific actions from user are required. If you want to comment on that or get some details, please visit HBASE-19282.
Thanks anastas Added link here.
.003 Set balance by table as per Dave's suggestion. Fix checkstyle and whitespace. Nothing on thread asking for new suggestion so let this be what we roll with in beta-1.

Played with setting SNAPPY on by default but was reminded that it could wreck havoc if the native lib was not available...

Caused by: java.lang.RuntimeException: native snappy library not available: this version of libhadoop was built without snappy support.

... so will skip on this one.

Can we change DEFAULT_NORMALIZATION_ENABLED to true in TableDescriptorBuilder.java since the region normalizer seems to be a useful feature?

  /**
   * Constant that denotes whether the table is normalized by default.
   */
public static final boolean DEFAULT_NORMALIZATION_ENABLED = false;
Let me try it daisuke.kobayashi
.005 enables normalizer by default. Removes balance by table. Lets see if the latter is responsible for the timeouts we're seeing in the retries here.

This message was automatically generated.

For compression, maybe we can loop over the available codecs and apply the first we find? It's on the creation only, so it's not that important if we take few more ms? That way most of the people will get snappy enabled by default, but some will get other settings? Worked with someone yesterday where they had way to many regions on HBase. By activating FAST_DIFF (because of the usecase) and Snappy their biggest table went from 860GB to 70GB... It really makes a big difference.

I disabled normalization on by default (see discussion on dev list "[DISCUSSION] Default configurations in hbase-2.0.0 hbase-default.xml "). It is easy to enable and run so little by way of barrier to trying it. See nice doc here on normalization: https://community.hortonworks.com/articles/54987/hbase-region-normalizer.html

Let me look at compression....

.006 turns off the region normalization. It leaves off balancing by table. This latter seems to cause timeouts... Will look into this a bit more.
